Quite interesting, would be cool if dragons didn't have tame states (taned/untamed) but instead had trust values. "Taming" would just raise the value. Spending time doing fun things with it (killing stuff, running, sleaping nearby, things like that) would also increase it. Depending on how high the value is the slower the value decreases (10 = -1 a second, 100 -0.1 a second) until a specific number would grant permanent tameness. This would mean that they can still not fully trust the player but tolerate their company

Brenn Boyer, that's not a good idea. Who would want to have to feed their parrots every time they wanted the fall damage protection?

I do want to ask the author to address a couple of things:

1) This feature would be sort of useless for as long as parrots fly off your shoulder every time you jump. What do you propose to get around this?

2 ) Wearing armor, even unenchanted, protects you from fall damage. Wouldn't it be a good idea to nerf this in order to make the parrots less OP?

if theyre gonna make a minecraft weeping angel they should at least try to make it scary
The problem with simply upgrading the damage of the creaking is that it would impose onto mojang's idea of a "vanilla start".

Another thing:
- They shouldn't make walking sounds unless they're very close to you
- They should all charge at you when you're breaking their block, even if you're seeing them.
- They should have several poses they switch into when they switch to being still, similar to the weeping angels
- They should probably be made invisible or changed to look differently while they're walking, since it looks pretty silly seeing them penguin-walk towards you.

To make getting hit by the Creaking more challenging, maybe every time a player is hit, all torches within 10 blocks of them break: this would only really be interesting if other mobs can spawn in the pale garden of course.

It would be cooler if the mob followed the player with its eyes, but if the creaking was close to the player when you look at it the creaking should close its eyes for more camouflage. If you want to really make the forest spooky then add vines that hang out of the trees leaves and if the player touches one, it will grab the player or mob and hold them upside down also your screen would be flipped upside down and the only way to escape would be to use a axe or sword on the wood-colored vine to break it. It would really give the vibe that the trees are alive and trying to get you making the whole thing really spooky.

Pealse

I think there is no more because Mojang isn't approaching them just right. For the Mob Vote both times Golems were on the list they lost to a mob that brought utility or new lore/items of interest.

Classical Golems are constructed for a purpose, a niche that is beneficial for the maker. Iron golems are melee defense, and Snow Golems (an almost useful) ranged defense. The copper and tuff while cute lacked a general gameplay use. Golems need utility purposes to win, being a random button pusher (when a chicken and pressure plates work) or a moving item frame isn't general enough. Now both golems displayed awesome mechanics that can balance gameplay with more powerful golems.

So what are niches, that Golems could be used?

-Smart Turrent (variation of range Defense), they stay in 1 spot (16 block range) so either weather/rust or need to be refilled with ammunition for balance.

-Alerting Guard (tweak the Glare idea), can walk along a light path (stays in light level edge) and "alarms" at hostiles near drawing iron golems to it. If you lead it with a leash it's inactive unless in a lite area, but could watch your back and alarm while mining. 

-Harvesters/sorters (quality of life grinders), farming, fishing, lumber, auto farmers, that take "naps" like the tuff golem does would give a ton of useful golems each could have unique conditions on top of controls, but fill in that niche of reducing grind for players.

While I would like to have more golems, what would these do? Keep in mind that all golems are spawned by being constructed out of blocks and are aligned with the player. The way you describe the magma golem seems to imply that it would spawn naturally and attack the player. The only evil golems in the franchise are the redstone golems in dungeons.

Mojang is also aware that more golems would be good for the game, as they have included them in mob votes the last two years, (though they both unfortunately lost. I still can't believe the tuff golem lost to the rascal.)

I like that this would make Elytras renewable which would help balancing the elytra supply on servers. I think you should elaborate more on the details of the mob though. How do they behave, neutral or agressive? And how do they fight? Just like any player would? That might be a bit boring.

Also, since there is no solid ground in the end, wouldn't the elytras they drop just fall into the void if they don't die over an island? Maybe there should be a way to prevent that, as that would steal the player's reward for defeating them. It would be unfortunate if the go-to method ended up sealing them in with blocks so they can't fly away.
